a.g: The revelation of the Qur'an is from Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
Indeed, We have sent down to you the Book, [O Muhammad], in truth. So worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion.

Unquestionably, for Allah is the pure religion. And those who take protectors besides Him [say], "We only worship them that they may bring us nearer to Allah in position." Indeed, Allah will judge between them concerning that over which they differ. Indeed, Allah does not guide he who is a liar and [confirmed] disbeliever.

Indeed, to Allah belongs the religion of pure sincerity [al-din al-khalis]. And He, the Exalted, said: "Except for those who repent, reform, and hold fast to Allah and make their religion [din] pure for Allah." And He, the Exalted, said: "So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord, let him do righteous work and not associate anyone in the worship of his Lord." This was revealed concerning one who acts for Allah but loves to be praised for it. And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Three things, concerning them the heart of a believing man is not treacherous: sincerity of action [ikhlas al-'amal] for Allah." And from Mus'ab ibn Sa'd, from his father, who said: My father thought he had superiority over those beneath him among the Companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, Allah, Mighty and Majestic, grants victory to this community only through its weak ones, their supplication, and their sincerity [ikhlas]." And from al-Hasan, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah, the Exalted, says: 'Sincerity [al-ikhlas] is a secret from My secrets; I have deposited it in the heart of whom I love from among My servants.'" And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, said: "Do not be concerned with the smallness of the action, but be concerned with its acceptance. For the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Mu'adh ibn Jabal: 'Make the action sincere [akhliá¹£ al-'amal], and a little of it will suffice you.'" And he, peace be upon him, said: "There is no servant who makes his action pure [yukhlis] for Allah for forty days except that the springs of wisdom [yanabi' al-hikmah] will appear from his heart [qalb] upon his tongue." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The first to be questioned on the Day of Resurrection are three: A man whom Allah granted knowledge ['ilm]. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'What did you do with what you knew?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would stand in prayer during the night and its ends during the day.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is a scholar. Behold, it was said.' And a man whom Allah granted wealth. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'I have bestowed favor upon you, so what did you do?' He will say: 'My Lord, I would give charity with it during the night and its ends during the day.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is generous. Behold, it was said.' And a man who was killed in the path of Allah, the Exalted. So Allah, the Exalted, will say: 'What did you do?' He will say: 'My Lord, You commanded with struggle [jihad], so I fought until I was killed.' He will say: 'You have lied.' And the angels will say: 'You have lied. Rather, you wanted it to be said: So-and-so is courageous. Behold, it was said.'" Abu Hurayrah said: Then the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, struck my thigh and said: "O Abu Hurayrah, those are the first of creation for whom the fire of Hell [nar jahannam] will be heated."

a.g: If Allah had intended to take a son, He could have chosen from what He creates whatever He willed. Exalted is He; He is Allah, the One, the Prevailing.

He created the heavens and earth in truth. He wraps the night over the day and wraps the day over the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term. Unquestionably, He is the Exalted in Might, the Perpetual Forgiver.

He created you from one soul. Then He made from it its mate, and He produced for you from the grazing livestock eight mates. He creates you in the wombs of your mothers, creation after creation, within three darknesses. That is Allah, your Lord; to Him belongs dominion. There is no deity except Him, so how are you averted?

If you disbelieve - indeed, Allah is Free from need of you. And He does not approve for His servants disbelief. And if you are grateful, He approves it for you; and no bearer of burdens will bear the burden of another. Then to your Lord is your return, and He will inform you about what you used to do. Indeed, He is Knowing of that within the breasts.

Indeed, for this reason the Sacred Law [al-Shar'] has magnified the command regarding the killing of children and regarding infanticide [al-wa'd], for it is a prevention of the completion of existence [tamam al-wujud]. To this, the one who said, "Coitus interruptus [al-'azl] is one of the two forms of infanticide," alluded. Therefore, the one who engages in intercourse is striving to complete what God, Exalted is He, loves to be completed, and the one who turns away is nullifying and wasting what God dislikes to be wasted. And due to God's love [mahabbah] for the survival [baqa'] of souls [al-nufus], He commanded feeding and urged towards it, and He expressed it through the worship of the loan, saying: "Who is it that will lend God a goodly loan?" If you say: Your statement that the survival of progeny and the soul is beloved [mahbub] implies that their annihilation [fana'] is disliked [makruh] in the sight of God, and this creates a distinction between death [al-mawt] and life [al-hayah] in relation to God's will [iradah]. Yet it is known that everything is by God's will [mashiyyah], and that God is Self-Sufficient [ghani] over all the worlds. So from where is their death distinguished from their life, or their survival from their annihilation, in His sight? Know that this statement is true, but a falsehood is intended by it. For what we have mentioned does not contradict attributing all existent things to God's will [iradah]â€”their good and their evil, their benefit and their harm. However, love [al-mahabbah] and dislike [al-karahiyah] are opposites, and both do not contradict the will [al-iradah]. For many a willed thing is disliked, and many a willed thing is beloved. Disobediences [al-ma'asi] are disliked, and they, despite the dislike, are willed. And acts of obedience [al-ta'at] are willed, and their determined existence is willed, beloved, and pleasing. As for disbelief [al-kufr] and evil [al-sharr], we do not say it is pleasing [mardiy] and beloved [mahbub], but rather it is willed [murad]. And God, Exalted is He, has said: "Nor is He pleased with disbelief for His servants." So how can annihilation [al-fana'] be in relation to God's love [mahabbah] and dislike [karahiyah] like survival [al-baqa']? For He, Exalted is He, says: "I have not hesitated in anything as I hesitate in seizing the soul of My believing servant. He dislikes death, and I dislike to distress him, yet death is inevitable for him." His statement, "death is inevitable for him," is an allusion to the precedence of the will [al-iradah] and the decree [al-taqdir] mentioned in His saying, Exalted is He: "We have decreed death among you," and in His saying, Exalted is He: "Who created death and life." And there is no contradiction between His saying, Exalted is He: "We have decreed death among you," and His saying: "and I dislike to distress him." However, clarifying the truth in this requires verifying the meaning of will [al-iradah], love [al-mahabbah], and dislike [al-karahiyah], and elucidating their realities [haqa'iq].

ğŸ“– Vol1 book 6
Indeed, He has linked victory to patience [sabr], so the Almighty said: "Yes, if you are patient [tasbiroo] and fear Allah and they come upon you in this onslaught, your Lord will reinforce you with five thousand angels, marked." And He has gathered for the patient [sabireen] matters not gathered for others, as He said: "Those are the ones upon whom are blessings from their Lord and mercy, and it is they who are the guided." So guidance [huda], mercy [rahma], and blessings [salawat] are gathered for the patient [sabireen]. To exhaust all the verses regarding the station of patience [sabr] would be lengthy. As for the narrations, He (peace be upon him) said: "Patience [sabr] is half of faith [iman]," according to what will come regarding the aspect of it being half. And He (peace be upon him) said: "The least of what you have been given is certainty [yaqin] and the resolve of patience [sabr]. Whoever is given his share of these two will not care what he missed of night prayer and daytime fasting. And for you to be patient [tasbiroo] upon what you are upon is more beloved to me than for every one of you to meet me with the like of the deeds of all of you. But I fear that the world [dunya] will be opened up to you after me, so you will deny one another, and the people of the heavens will deny you. At that time, whoever is patient [sabara] and seeks reward will attain the perfection of his reward." Then he recited the saying of the Almighty: "What is with you will be exhausted, and what is with Allah is lasting. And We will surely give those who were patient [sabaru] their reward," the verse. And Jabir narrated that he (peace be upon him) was asked about faith [iman], and he said: "Patience [sabr] and generosity." And he also said: "Patience [sabr] is a treasure from the treasures of Paradise." And he was asked once, "What is faith [iman]?" He said: "Patience [sabr]." This resembles his saying (peace be upon him): "The Hajj is 'Arafah," meaning the greatest part of Hajj is 'Arafah. And he (peace be upon him) also said: "The best of deeds are those you compel your souls [nufus] to do." And it was said that Allah the Almighty revealed to Dawud (peace be upon him): "Adorn yourself with My attributes, and among My attributes is that I am the Patient [al-Sabur]." And in the hadith of 'Ata' from Ibn 'Abbas: When the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) entered upon the Ansar, he said: "Are you believers [mu'minoon]?" They were silent. 'Umar said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "And what is the sign of your faith [iman]?" They said: "We give thanks in ease, we are patient [nasbiru] in hardship, and we are content with the decree." He (peace be upon him) said: "Believers [mu'minoon], by the Lord of the Ka'bah!" And he (peace be upon him) said: "When the Day of Resurrection comes, the people of deeds will be brought, and their deeds will be weighed in the scales: the people of prayer, fasting, charity, and Hajj. Then the people of affliction will be brought, and no scales will be set up for them, nor any record spread open for them. Reward will be poured upon them in torrents, just as affliction was poured upon them in torrents. So the people of ease in the world [dunya] will wish that their bodies had been cut with scissors, due to what they see of the reward that the people of affliction take away." That is the meaning of His saying, the Almighty: "Indeed, the patient [sabiroon] will be given their reward without account."

a.g: Say, [O Muhammad], "Indeed, I have been commanded to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion.
And I have been commanded to be the first [among you] of the Muslims."
Say, "Indeed I fear, if I should disobey my Lord, the punishment of a tremendous Day."
Say, "Allah [alone] do I worship, sincere to Him in my religion,
So worship what you will besides Him." Say, "Indeed, the losers are the ones who will lose themselves and their families on the Day of Resurrection. Unquestionably, that is the manifest loss."
They will have canopies of fire above them and below them, canopies. By that Allah threatens His servants. O My servants, then fear Me.

a.g: Then, is one who has deserved the decree of punishment [to be guided]? Then, can you save one who is in the Fire?
But those who have feared their Lord - for them are chambers, above them chambers built high, beneath which rivers flow. [This is] the promise of Allah. Allah does not fail in [His] promise.

Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and makes it flow as springs [and rivers] in the earth; then He produces thereby crops of varying colors; then they dry and you see them turned yellow; then He makes them [scattered] debris. Indeed in that is a reminder for those of understanding.

So is one whose breast Allah has expanded to [accept] Islam and he is upon a light from his Lord [like one whose heart rejects it]? Then woe to those whose hearts are hardened against the remembrance of Allah. Those are in manifest error.

Indeed, likewise in the heart [qalb] there is an innate faculty called the Divine Light [al-nur al-ilahi], due to His saying, exalted is He: "Is he whose breast [sadr] God has expanded for Islam, so he is upon a light [nur] from his Lord?" And it has been called the intellect [al-'aql], and it has been called the inner insight [al-basira al-batina], and it has been called the light of faith [nur al-iman] and certainty [al-yaqin]. There is no meaning in busying oneself with the names, for the terminologies differ. The weak one imagines that the difference occurs in the meanings, because the weak one seeks the meanings from the words, and this is the opposite of what is required. The heart [qalb] is distinguished from all other parts of the body by a quality through which it perceives meanings that are neither imagined nor sensed, such as perceiving the creation of the world [khalq al-'alam] or its need for an Ancient Creator, a Manager, Wise, described with divine attributes. And it is permissible to name that innate faculty 'intellect' [al-'aql] on the condition that one does not understand from the term 'intellect' that by which the methods of disputation and debate are perceived, for the name 'intellect' has become famous with this [meaning], and for this reason some of the Sufis have censured it. Otherwise, the quality by which man is distinguished from the beasts and by which he perceives the knowledge [ma'rifa] of God, exalted is He, is the most noble of qualities, so it should not be censured. This innate faculty was created so that through it the realities [haqa'iq] of all matters may be known. The requirement of its nature is knowledge [ma'rifa] and understanding ['ilm], and that is its delight, just as the requirement of all other innate faculties is their delight.

a.g: Allah has sent down the best statement: a consistent Book wherein is reiteration. The skins shiver therefrom of those who fear their Lord; then their skins and their hearts relax at the remembrance of Allah. That is the guidance of Allah by which He guides whom He wills. And one whom Allah leaves astray - for him there is no guide.

Indeed, His saying, the Most High: "Repeated verses [mathani] at which the skins of those who fear their Lord shiver, then their skins and their hearts soften to the remembrance of Allah." And all that occurs in the soul [nafs] following listening is a state of spiritual experience [wajd]. So tranquility [tuma'ninah], shivering [iqsh'iar], awe [khashyah], and the softening of the heart [qalb]â€”all of that is a state of spiritual experience [wajd]. And Allah, the Most High, has said: "The believers are only those whose hearts [qulub] tremble when Allah is mentioned." And He, the Most High, has said: "If We had sent down this Qur'an upon a mountain, you would have seen it humbled and split asunder from the fear of Allah." So trembling [wajal] and humility [khushu'] are a state of spiritual experience [wajd] from the category of spiritual states [ahwal], even if it is not from the category of unveilings [mukashafat]. But it may become a cause for unveilings [mukashafat] and spiritual promptings [tanbihat].

a.g: Then is he who will shield with his face the worst of the punishment on the Day of Resurrection [like one secure from it]? And it will be said to the wrongdoers, "Taste what you used to earn."
Those before them denied, and punishment came upon them from where they did not perceive.
So Allah made them taste disgrace in worldly life. But the punishment of the Hereafter is greater, if they only knew.
And We have certainly presented for the people in this Qur'an from every [kind of] example - that they might remember.
[It is] an Arabic Qur'an, without any deviance that they might become righteous.
Allah presents an example: a slave owned by quarreling partners and another belonging exclusively to one man - are they equal in comparison? Praise be to Allah! But most of them do not know.
Indeed, you are to die, and indeed, they are to die.

Indeed, when His words descended - "Indeed, you are to die [innaka mayyit], and indeed they are to die [wa innahum mayyitun]. Then indeed you, on the Day of Resurrection, before your Lord, will dispute" - Al-Zubair said, "O Messenger of God, will our past disputes be repeated for us?" And none of the Muslims were in a state like that of Abu Bakr and Al-Abbas, for God Almighty supported them with success [tawfiq] and correctness [sadad]. And the people did not come to their senses except by the statement of Abu Bakr, until Al-Abbas came and said, "By God, besides whom there is no god, the Messenger of God has indeed tasted death [dhaqa al-mawt], and he indeed said while he was among you: 'Indeed, you are to die, and indeed they are to die. Then indeed you, on the Day of Resurrection, before your Lord, will dispute.'" And the news reached Abu Bakr while he was with the Banu Al-Harith ibn Al-Khazraj, so he came and entered upon the Messenger of God. He looked at him, then leaned over him and kissed him, then said, "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of God. God Almighty would not make you taste death twice. For by God, the Messenger of God has indeed died [tuwuffiya]." Then he went out to the people and said, "O people, whoever was worshipping Muhammad, then Muhammad has died. And whoever was worshipping the Lord of Muhammad, then He is Living [hayy], does not die. God Almighty has said: 'And Muhammad is not but a messenger; messengers have passed before him. So if he dies or is killed, will you turn back on your heels?'" So it was as if the people had not heard this verse until that day.

And none of the Muslims were in a state like that of Abu Bakr and Al-Abbas, for God Almighty supported them with success [tawfiq] and correctness [sadad]. And the people did not come to their senses except by the statement of Abu Bakr, until Al-Abbas came and said, "By God, besides whom there is no god, the Messenger of God has indeed tasted death [dhaqa al-mawt], and he indeed said while he was among you: 'Indeed, you are to die, and indeed they are to die. Then indeed you, on the Day of Resurrection, before your Lord, will dispute.'" And the news reached Abu Bakr while he was with the Banu Al-Harith ibn Al-Khazraj, so he came and entered upon the Messenger of God. He looked at him, then leaned over him and kissed him, then said, "May my father and mother be sacrificed for you, O Messenger of God. God Almighty would not make you taste death twice. For by God, the Messenger of God has indeed died [tuwuffiya]." Then he went out to the people and said, "O people, whoever was worshipping Muhammad, then Muhammad has died. And whoever was worshipping the Lord of Muhammad, then He is Living [hayy], does not die. God Almighty has said: 'And Muhammad is not but a messenger; messengers have passed before him. So if he dies or is killed, will you turn back on your heels?'" So it was as if the people had not heard this verse until that day.

Indeed, the Hereafter [al-akhirah] is upon four ranks: The first, which is the highest, is the governance [siyasah] of the Prophets, peace be upon them, and their rule over the elite [al-khassah] and the common people [al-'ammah] all together, in their outward [zahir] and inward [batin] states. The second is the successors [al-khulafa'], the kings, and the sultans, and their rule over the elite and the common people all together, but over their outward state only, not over their inward state. The third is the knowers of God, Mighty and Majestic is He, and of His religion, who are the inheritors of the Prophets, and their rule is over the inward state of the elite only, and the understanding of the common people does not rise to benefit from them, nor does their power extend to managing their outward states through obligation, prevention, and legislation. The fourth is the preachers [al-wu'az], and their rule is over the inward states of the common people only. The most noble of these four crafts after prophethood is imparting knowledge [ifadat al-'ilm] and refining the souls [nufus] of people from the blameworthy, destructive character traits and guiding them to the praiseworthy, felicitous character traits, and this is what is intended by teaching. We only said that this is better than all other professions and crafts because the nobility of crafts is known by three matters: either by consideration of the innate faculty [gharizah] by which one attains its knowledge, like the superiority of intellectual faculties over linguistic ones, for wisdom [hikmah] is perceived by the intellect [al-'aql] and language by hearing, and the intellect is nobler than hearing. Or by looking at the generality of benefit, like the superiority of agriculture over goldsmithing. Or by observing the locus [mahall] in which the management occurs, like the superiority of goldsmithing over tanning, for the locus of one is gold and the locus of the other is the skin of a dead animal. And it is not hidden that the religious sciences, which are the jurisprudence [fiqh] of the path to the Hereafter, are only attained by the perfection of the intellect and the clarity of intelligence, and the intellect is the noblest of human attributes, as its clarification will come later, for by it the trust [amanah] of God is accepted and by it one attains proximity to God, Glorified is He. As for the generality of benefit, there is no doubt in it, for its benefit and its fruit is the felicity [sa'adah] of the Hereafter. As for the nobility of the locus, how can it be hidden, when the teacher manages the hearts [qulub] of humans and their souls [nufus], and the noblest existent on earth is the human species, and the noblest part of the essences [jawhar] of a human is his heart, and the teacher is occupied with perfecting it, polishing it, purifying it, and leading it to proximity [qurb] to God, Mighty and Majestic is He. So teaching knowledge is, from one aspect, worship ['ibadah] for God, Exalted is He, and from another aspect, vicegerency [khilafah] for God, Exalted is He, and it is among the greatest vicegerencies of God, for God, Exalted is He, has opened upon the heart of the knower [al-'alim] the knowledge which is His most specific attribute, so he is like the treasurer for the most precious of His treasuries. Then he is permitted to spend from it upon everyone in need of it. So what rank is greater than the servant being an intermediary between his Lord, Glorified is He, and His creation in bringing them nearer to God and leading them to the Garden of Refuge? May God make us among them by His grace, and may God send blessings upon every chosen servant. **The Second Chapter: On the Praiseworthy and Blameworthy Knowledge, Their Divisions and Their Rulings, and in it is a clarification of what is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn] and what is a communal obligation [fard kifayah], and a clarification of the position of speech [kalam] and jurisprudence [fiqh] within the knowledge of the religionâ€”to what limit it isâ€”and the superiority of the knowledge of the Hereafter.** **Clarification of the Knowledge Which is an Individual Obligation** The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Seeking knowledge is an obligation upon every Muslim." And he also said, peace and blessings be upon him: "Seek knowledge, even if it is in China." And the people differed regarding the knowledge which is an obligation upon every Muslim, so they split into more than twenty sects concerning it, and we will not prolong by transmitting the details. But its essence is that every group applied the obligation to the knowledge they were engaged in. So the theologians [al-mutakallimun] said: It is the knowledge of theological discourse ['ilm al-kalam], for by it monotheism [al-tawhid] is realized and the Essence of God, Glorified is He, and His attributes are known. And the jurists [al-fuqaha'] said: It is the knowledge of jurisprudence ['ilm al-fiqh], for by it the acts of worship ['ibadat], the lawful [halal] and the prohibited [haram], and what is forbidden and what is permitted in transactions are known, and they meant by it what individuals need, excluding rare occurrences. And the exegetes [al-mufassirun] and the hadith scholars [al-muhaddithun] said: It is the knowledge of the Book and the Sunnah, for by them one attains all the sciences. And the Sufis [al-mutasawwifah] said: What is intended by it is this knowledge. So some of them said: It is the knowledge of the servant of his state [hal] and his station [maqam] from God, Mighty and Majestic is He. And some of them said: It is knowledge of sincerity [ikhlas] and the diseases of the souls [afat al-nufus] and distinguishing the prompting of the angel from the prompting of the devil. And some of them said: It is the knowledge of the inward [al-batin], and that is obligatory upon specific people who are its people, and they diverted the wording from its generality. And Abu Talib al-Makki said: It is the knowledge of what the hadith which contains the foundations of Islam comprises, and it is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Islam is built upon five: the testimony that there is no god but God..." to the end of the hadith. Because the obligation is these five, so knowledge of the manner of acting upon them and the manner of their obligation becomes obligatory. And what the accomplished one should be decisive about and have no doubt in is what we will mention, and it is that knowledge, as we presented in the introduction of the book, is divided into the knowledge of transaction ['ilm al-mu'amalah] and the knowledge of unveiling ['ilm al-mukashafah], and what is intended by this knowledge is nothing but the knowledge of transaction. And the transaction which the rational, mature servant is charged to act upon is of three kinds: belief [i'tiqad], action [fi'l], and abstention [tark]. So when the rational man reaches maturity... and He, Exalted is He, said: "So who is more unjust than one who lies about God and denies the truth when it has come to him?" (Az-Zumar: 32)

That Allah may remove from them the worst of what they did and reward them their due for the best of what they used to do.

a.g: And whoever Allah guides - for him there is no misleader. Is not Allah Exalted in Might and Owner of Retribution?

And if you asked them, "Who created the heavens and the earth?" they would surely say, "Allah." Say, "Then have you considered what you invoke besides Allah? If Allah intended me harm, are they removers of His harm; or if He intended me mercy, are they withholders of His mercy?" Say, "Sufficient for me is Allah; upon Him [alone] rely the [wise] reliers."
Say, "O my people, work according to your position, [for] indeed, I am working; and you are going to know
To whom will come a torment disgracing him and on whom will descend an enduring punishment."

Indeed, We sent down to you the Book for the people in truth. So whoever is guided - it is for [the benefit of] his soul; and whoever goes astray only goes astray to its detriment. And you are not a manager over them.

Allah takes the souls at the time of their death, and those that do not die [He takes] during their sleep. Then He keeps those for which He has decreed death and releases the others for a specified term. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

ğŸ“– Vol1 book 10
Indeed, if you say: How can one reconcile Divine Oneness [tawhid] and Sacred Law [shar']? For the meaning of Oneness [tawhid] is that there is no agent [fa'il] except God, Exalted is He; and the meaning of the Sacred Law [shar'] is affirming actions [af'al] for the servants [ibad]. If the servant [abd] is an agent [fa'il], then how can God, Exalted is He, be the agent [fa'il]? And if God, Exalted is He, is the agent [fa'il], then how can the servant [abd] be an agent [fa'il]? An effect [maf'ul] between two agents [fa'ilayn] is not comprehensible? Then I say: Yes, that is not comprehensible if the agent [fa'il] has a single meaning. But if it has two meanings, and the name is a general term [mujmal] oscillating between them, there is no contradiction. Just as it is said: 'The commander [amir] killed so-and-so,' and it is said: 'The executioner [jallad] killed him.' However, the commander [amir] is a killer [qatil] in one sense, and the executioner [jallad] is a killer [qatil] in another sense. Likewise, the servant [abd] is an agent [fa'il] in one sense, and God, Mighty and Majestic, is an agent [fa'il] in another sense. For the meaning of God, Exalted is He, being the agent [fa'il] is that He is the Inventor [mukhtari'], the Bringer-into-Being [mawjid]. And the meaning of the servant [abd] being an agent [fa'il] is that he is the locus [mahall] in which power [qudra] was created after will [irada] was created in him, after knowledge [ilm] was created in him. Thus, power [qudra] became connected to will [irada], and movement [haraka] became connected to power [qudra] with the connection of a condition [shart] to what is conditioned [mashrut]. And it became connected to the power [qudra] of God with the connection of an effect [ma'lul] to its cause [illa] and the connection of the invented [mukhtara'] to the Inventor [mukhtari']. Everything that has a connection to a power [qudra], then the locus [mahall] of that power [qudra] is called an agent [fa'il] for it, however the connection may be. Just as the executioner [jallad] is called a killer [qatil] and the commander [amir] is called a killer [qatil], because the killing [qatl] was connected to the power [qudra] of both of them, but in two different ways. Therefore, it was called an action [fi'l] for both of them. Likewise is the connection of the foreordained things [maqdurat] to the two powers [qudratayn]. And due to the correspondence and alignment of this, God, Exalted is He, ascribed the actions [af'al] in the Qur'an at one time to the angels [mala'ika] and at another time to the servants [ibad], and He ascribed the very same actions [af'al] at another time to Himself. Thus, God, Exalted is He, said concerning death [mawt]: "Say, 'The Angel of Death [malak al-mawt] takes you'" (32:11). Then He, Mighty and Majestic, said: "It is God who takes the souls [anfus] at the time of their death [mawt]" (39:42).

a.g: Or have they taken other than Allah as intercessors? Say, "Even though they do not possess [power over] anything, nor do they reason?"
Say, "To Allah belongs [the right to allow] intercession entirely. To Him belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. Then to Him you will be returned."

ğŸ“– Vol1 book 5
Indeed, when the verse concerning the innocence of 'A'ishah, may God be pleased with her, was revealed in the story of the slander, Abu Bakr, may God be pleased with him, said: "Rise and kiss the head of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him." She said: "By God, I will not do it, and I praise none but God." He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Leave her, O Abu Bakr." In another narration, she, may God be pleased with her, said to Abu Bakr, may God be pleased with him: "I praise God, not you and not your companion." And the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, did not disapprove of her for that, even though the revelation [wahy] had reached her through the tongue of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him. And seeing things other than God, glorified and exalted is He, is a description of the disbelievers. God, the Exalted, says: "And when God alone is mentioned, the hearts [qulub] of those who do not believe in the Hereafter [Akhirah] shrink with aversion, but when those other than Him are mentioned, behold, they rejoice." (Az-Zumar: 45) And whoever does not purify his inner being [batin] from seeing intermediaries [wasait] except insofar as they are intermediaries, it is as if he has not been freed from the hidden secret of hidden polytheism [shirk khafi]. So let him be mindful of God, glorified and exalted is He, in purifying his declaration of God's oneness [tawhid] from the impurities of polytheism [shirk] and its stains.

a.g: And there will appear to them the evils they had earned, and they will be enveloped by what they used to ridicule.

And when adversity touches man, he calls upon Us; then when We bestow on him a favor from Us, he says, "I have only been given it because of [my] knowledge." Rather, it is a trial, but most of them do not know.
Those before them had already said it, but they were not availed by what they used to earn.

And the evil consequences of what they earned struck them. And those who have wronged of these [people] will be afflicted by the evil consequences of what they earned; and they will not cause failure.
Do they not know that Allah extends provision for whom He wills and restricts [it]? Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe.
Say, "O My servants who have transgressed against themselves [by sinning], do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful."

a.g: And return [in repentance] to your Lord and submit to Him before the punishment comes upon you; then you will not be helped.
And follow the best of what was revealed to you from your Lord before the punishment comes upon you suddenly while you do not perceive,
Lest a soul should say, "Oh [how great is] my regret over what I neglected in regard to Allah and that I was among the mockers."
Or [lest] it say, "If only Allah had guided me, I would have been among the righteous."
Or [lest] it say when it sees the punishment, "If only I had another turn so I could be among the doers of good."
But yes, there had come to you My verses, but you denied them and were arrogant, and you were among the disbelievers.
And on the Day of Resurrection you will see those who lied about Allah [with] their faces blackened. Is there not in Hell a residence for the arrogant?

a.g: And Allah will save those who feared Him by their attainment; no evil will touch them, nor will they grieve.
Allah is the Creator of all things, and He is, over all things, Disposer of affairs.
To Him belong the keys of the heavens and the earth. And they who disbelieve in the verses of Allah - it is those who are the losers.
Say, [O Muhammad], "Is it other than Allah that you order me to worship, O ignorant ones?"
And it was already revealed to you and to those before you that if you should associate [anything] with Allah, your work would surely become worthless, and you would surely be among the losers."
Rather, worship [only] Allah and be among the grateful.

They have not appraised Allah with true appraisal, while the earth entirely will be [within] His grip on the Day of Resurrection, and the heavens will be folded in His right hand. Exalted is He and high above what they associate with Him.

And the Horn will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on.

And contemplate first what strikes the hearing of the inhabitants of the graves from the intensity of the blowing of the Trumpet [as-sur]. For it is a single cry, through which the graves split open over the heads of the dead, and they surge forth all at once. So imagine yourself, having leapt up, your face altered, your body dust-covered from your head to your feet with the dust of your grave, stunned from the intensity of the blow, your eyes fixed towards the call. And the creation has surged forth in a single surge from the graves in which their tribulation was prolonged, and alarm and terror have roused them, added to what was with them of sorrows, griefs, and the intensity of waiting for the final outcome of the matter, as the Most High has said: "And the Trumpet [as-sur] will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on." So if there were nothing before the dead except the terror of that blowing, that would be sufficient to be guarded against. For it is a blowing and a cry through which whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls deadâ€”meaning they die from itâ€”except whom Allah wills, and that is some of the angels. And for that reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "How can I be at ease when the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur] has placed the horn in his mouth, lowered his forehead, and inclined his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?" Muqatil said: The Trumpet [as-sur] is the horn. That is because Israfil, upon him be peace, places his mouth upon the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circumference of the head of the horn is like the width of the heavens and the earth. And he is fixing his gaze towards the Throne, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. And when he blows, whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls deadâ€”meaning every living creature dies from the intensity of the terrorâ€”except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death. Then He commands the Angel of Death to seize the soul of Jibril, then the soul of Mika'il, then the soul of Israfil. Then He commands the Angel of Death, and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Barzakh for forty years. Then Allah, the Most High, revives Israfil and commands him to blow the second blowing. That is His saying, the Most High: "Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on"â€”upon their feet, looking towards the Resurrection. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "When I was sent, I was sent to the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur], and he gestured with it to his mouth, and placed one foot forward and the other back, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow. So beware of the blowing." So contemplate the creatures and their abasement, their brokenness, and their submission at the time of being sent forth, in fear of this blow and in waiting for what will be decreed for them of felicity or wretchedness. And you are among them, broken as they are broken, bewildered as they are bewildered. Rather, if you were in the world [ad-dunya] among the affluent and the wealthy who live in luxury, then the kings of the earth...

And contemplate first what strikes the hearing of the inhabitants of the graves from the intensity of the blowing of the Trumpet [as-sur]. For it is a single cry, through which the graves split open over the heads of the dead, and they surge forth all at once. So imagine yourself, having leapt up, your face altered, your body dust-covered from your head to your feet with the dust of your grave, stunned from the intensity of the blow, your eyes fixed towards the call. And the creation has surged forth in a single surge from the graves in which their tribulation was prolonged, and alarm and terror have roused them, added to what was with them of sorrows, griefs, and the intensity of waiting for the final outcome of the matter, as the Most High has said: "And the Trumpet [as-sur] will be blown, and whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will fall dead except whom Allah wills. Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on." So if there were nothing before the dead except the terror of that blowing, that would be sufficient to be guarded against. For it is a blowing and a cry through which whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls deadâ€”meaning they die from itâ€”except whom Allah wills, and that is some of the angels. And for that reason, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "How can I be at ease when the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur] has placed the horn in his mouth, lowered his forehead, and inclined his ear, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow?" Muqatil said: The Trumpet [as-sur] is the horn. That is because Israfil, upon him be peace, places his mouth upon the horn like the form of a trumpet, and the circumference of the head of the horn is like the width of the heavens and the earth. And he is fixing his gaze towards the Throne, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow the first blowing. And when he blows, whoever is in the heavens and the earth falls deadâ€”meaning every living creature dies from the intensity of the terrorâ€”except whom Allah wills, and that is Jibril, Mika'il, Israfil, and the Angel of Death. Then He commands the Angel of Death to seize the soul of Jibril, then the soul of Mika'il, then the soul of Israfil. Then He commands the Angel of Death, and he dies. Then the creation remains after the first blowing in the Barzakh for forty years. Then Allah, the Most High, revives Israfil and commands him to blow the second blowing. That is His saying, the Most High: "Then it will be blown again, and at once they will be standing, looking on"â€”upon their feet, looking towards the Resurrection. And the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "When I was sent, I was sent to the bearer of the Trumpet [as-sur], and he gestured with it to his mouth, and placed one foot forward and the other back, waiting for when he will be commanded to blow. So beware of the blowing." So contemplate the creatures and their abasement, their brokenness, and their submission at the time of being sent forth, in fear of this blow and in waiting for what will be decreed for them of felicity or wretchedness. And you are among them, broken as they are broken, bewildered as they are bewildered. Indeed, and from 'Asim bin Damrah, from 'Ali, may God honor his face, that he mentioned the Fire and magnified its affair with a mention I do not retain, then he said: **"And those who feared their Lord will be led to Paradise in groups."** [Quran 39:73] Until, when they reached a gate from among its gates, they found at it a tree, from beneath its trunk emerge two springs flowing. Then they reached Paradise, and its keepers said to them: "Peace be upon you, you have done well, so enter it, abiding eternally."
